div.l: And with þe staf she drough ay nere ⁊and nere
And wende han hitte þis aleyn atte fulle
And smoot þe mellere on the pilede sculle
Þat down he goþ ⁊and cryede harraw y dye
Thise clerkes bet him wel and lete him lye
And greythen hem ⁊and toke here hors a non
And ek here mele ⁊and on here wei þei gon
And atte Melle yet þei toke here cake
Of half a busshel flour ful wel I bake
Thus is þe proude Mellere wel y bete
And hath I lost þe gryndyng of the whete
And paied for þe soper eủery dele
Of Aleyn and of Iohn þat bette him wele
His wif is swyued and his doughter als
Loo such it is a Mellere to be fals
And þer fore þis ꝓproủerbe is seide ful soth
Him thar not wene wel þat yuel doth
A gilour shal him self bigiled be
And god that sitteth highe īn mageste
Saue alle this companye grete ⁊and smale
Thus haue I quyt þe Mellere in my tale
Here begynneth the ꝓprolog͗e of the Coke
The Cook of london while þe Reue spak
For ioye him þoughte he clawede hīm on the bak
Ha ha qduod he for cristes passion
This Mellere hath a sharp conclusion
Vppon his argument of herbigage
Wel seide salamon in his langage
Ne bring not eủery man in to þin hous
For herberwinge be nyghte is ꝑperilous
Wel oughte a man auysed for to be
Whom þat he broughte in to his pⁱriuyte
I pray to god so yeue me sorwen ⁊and kare
If eủere sithen I highte hogge of ware
Herde I Mellere bett̉ere I sette a werke
He hadde a Iape of malice in þe derke
And þerfore yf ye vouche saf to here
But god for bede þat we stynte here
A tale of me þat am a poure man
I wil yow telle as wel as eủere I can
A litil Iape that fille in oure citee
